results.title: This happy breed
results.creator_credit: David Lean, Cineguild Production and Noel Coward
results.brief_description: This affectionate tribute to the ordinary man is a panoramic story of the life of a London family during the two World Wars. Based on Noel Coward’s successful play (he also wrote the musical score), the film chronicles the Gibbons family from 1919 to 1939, and was released during the Second World War as part of the British film industry’s war effort. Robert Newton and Celia Johnson are Frank and Ethel Gibbons who, with their daughters Queenie (Kay Walsh) and Phyllis (Betty Fleetwood), face the day to day crises of ordinary life to survive as both individuals and as a family. Stanley Holloway and a very young John Mills star in this production along with narrator Laurence Olivier.

results.title: Bride of Chucky
results.creator_credit: Ronny Yu, David Kirschner, Grace Gilroy and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: This is the fourth, and without a doubt the best in the controversial ‘Child’s play’ series. In the latest instalment Chucky (voiced supplied by Brad Dourif), the benevolent child’s toy is bought back to life in this inventive and witty sequel which plays more like a demented homage to ‘Bride of Frankenstein’. The sinister looking doll which is possessed by the evil spirit of a serial killer is resurrected from the dead by his unbalanced goth girlfriend (played with relish by Jennifer Tilly), who has wedding bells on her mind. However Chucky has more sinister intentions than marriage, when he and his trailer trash bride stow away with two runaway teens wrongly accused of murder. Hong Kong director Ronny Yu (‘Bride with the white hair’), and writer Don Mancini have fashioned a wonderfully irresponsible film which proudly wears it’s horror film references on its sleeve, giving the series some surreal, clever twists and turns. Cast also includes John Ritter, Alexis Arquette and Katherine Heigl.

results.title: John Carpenter's Vampires
results.creator_credit: John Carpenter, Sandy King and Largo Entertainment
results.brief_description: Mainly working within the parameters of the horror genre, few director’s have the popularity and cult status to warrant their name in the films title, however John Carpenter (“Halloween”, “The Thing”, “Escape from New York”, “Assault on Precinct 13”) has the body of work and the loyal followers to back it up. Based on John Steakley’s novel, “Vampires” stars James Woods as Jack Crow, a sadistic vampire slayer working for the Vatican and searching for the 600 year old originator of the blood curse. Crow and his crew of vampire hunters end up in a small town in New Mexico where they uncover a ‘nest’ of the undead. As bait they use a newly bitten prostitute (Sheryl Lee) who now has telepathic links to the master, in an effort to trap the head bloodsucker. Cast also includes Daniel Baldwin, Thomas Ian Griffith, Maximillian Schell, and Tim Guinee. Music by John Carpenter.

results.title: Violent Cop = Sono otoko kyobo ni tsuki (D)
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Kazuyoshi Okuyama, Bandai Visual Company and Shochiku-Fuji Co
results.brief_description: Takeshi Kitano’s aptly named “Violent cop” is a sadistic and offbeat exercise in screen violence. Expected comparisons to the gleeful revenge soaked fantasies and moral righteousness of the Dirty Harry series are quickly dissipated by Kitano’s deadpan, morally ambiguous protagonist and the unexpected comic moments sandwiched between the painful and bleak depictions of violence. ‘Beat’ Takeshi plays a hardened cop whose special brand of rough justice lands him in bad favor with his supervisors. Things begin to spiral out of control when he tries to help a corrupt colleague who has become involved with the Yakuza. To make matters worse his mentally unstable sister is also lured into the gang, accumulating into the inevitable bloody showdown. In Japanese with English subtitles Cast also includes Maiko Kawakami, Makoto Ashikawa, Shigeru Hiraizumi and Shiro Sano.

results.title: Sonatine
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Bandai Visual Company and Shouchiku Daiichi Kougyo
results.brief_description: Like most Takeshi Kitano films, the body of this story is made up of the small details within the greater narrative, like the contemplative moments a couple shares, or the morbid retrospections before a bloody action shoot-out. The quiet observations momentarily disrupted by a sudden outburst of intense violence. In this glorious low tempo Yakuza film Kitano stars as a stoic gangster in desperate need of a holiday. When a ‘job’ goes wrong, Kitano and his gang are forced to retreat to a seaside hideaway. What follows is a series of beautifully observed deadpan scenes which constantly challenge our notions of what we have come to expect from the gangster genre. In Japanese with English subtitles. Cast includes Aya Kikumai, Tetsu Watanabe, Masanobu Katsumura, Sesumu Terajima and Ren Osugi.

results.title: The Terror of Tiny Town
results.creator_credit: Sam Newfield, Abe Meyer, Bert Sternbach, Jed Buell, Columbia Pictures Corporation and Principal Productions
results.brief_description: This movie has all the classic elements usually found in westerns of the 1930’s - 1950’s. The dashing hero, the fair damsel in need of rescuing, the despised villain, singing, dancing, and the big chase scene. It’s all here. The one thing that separates this movie from any other western is the cast. 100% midgets, the entire movie is cast with actors under the height of 4 feet 8 inches, with a couple of fellas who just might make three feet. You haven’t seen a true chase scene until you see a group of guys chasing each other on Shetland ponies.

results.title: The Lodger
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock, Carlyle Blackwell Sr, Sir Michael Balcon and Gainsborough Pictures
results.brief_description: While ‘The Lodger’ was not director Alfred Hitchcock’s first film, it was the first to truly deserve the designation “A Hitchcock Picture”. British matinee idol Ivor Novello plays Jonathan Drew, a quiet, secretive young man who rents a room in a London boarding house. Drew’s arrival coincides with the reign of terror orchestrated by Jack the Ripper. As the film progresses, circumstantial evidence begins to mount, pointing to Drew as the selfsame Ripper. In the original story by Mrs Belloc-Lownes, suspicions concerning Drew were confirmed; but Ivor Novello was a star of the first magnitude, and stars of the first magnitude just didn’t play murderers back in 1926. Thus, we learn at the last possible moment that Drew is innocent, and is in fact on the trail of the Ripper himself. Hitchcock makes his cameo appearance at a desk in the newsroom early in the film. Some people claim he also appears later in the crowd watching the arrest. Hitchcock wanted an ambiguous ending to the film, but the studio wouldn’t allow it to be implied that Ivor Novello might actually be the murderer.

results.title: Hana-Bi = Fireworks
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Masayuki Mori, Takio Yoshida, Yasushi Tsuge and Office Kitano
results.brief_description: ‘Hana-bi’ might of launched director and star Takeshi Kitano onto the international film scene but the prolific film maker (who also goes by the name ‘Beat’ Takeshi) was already a star in his home country where he wears many creative hats. Besides feature films he works extensively in television, is also known as a comedian and has now added painter to his impressive resume. (Kitano’s artwork is on display throughout Hana-bi) Kitano’s genius lies in the radically contrasting rhythm of narrative and style. One minute a poignant and understated drama about a cop (Kitano) and his terminally ill wife (Kayoko Kishimoto), the next an excessively violent police film, punctuated by bloody scenes of mayhem. The two radically different strands are seamlessly bought together by Kitano’s restrained direction, the mosaic editing style, quirky characterisations and the fine musical score by Joe Hisaishi. In Japanese with English subtitles Cast also includes Ren Osugi and Susumu Terajima. (Awards: Golden Lion 1997 Venice Film Festival)

results.title: The Linguini incident
results.creator_credit: Richard Shepard, Arnold Orgolini and Linguini Productions
results.brief_description: 2 women with unfulfilled dreams and 1 man with a gambling debt embark on a pact to rob a nightclub. Waitress Lucy (Rosanna Arquette) aspires to be Lucy the Ethereal, a female Houdini, but has not made a spectacular escape since childhood. Her friend, Viv (Eszter Balint), wants to create her own line of avant-garde lingerie but is finding it hard to make a start, and Monte (David Bowie) is a gambling addict who says he needs to marry before the end of the week or his life is in danger. Together, they rob the nightclub and Lucy agrees to marry Monte, however when the wedding falls through Monte loses yet another bet and it’s up to be Lucy to be Lucy the Ethereal once and for all to settle the accumulated $4 million dollar debt. Bowie’s real life wife, Iman, makes a cameo as a nightclub guest.

results.title: Superman II
results.creator_credit: Richard Lester, Pierre Spengler and Alexander Salkind and Ilya Salkind Productions
results.brief_description: In this sequel to “Superman: the movie”, the Man of Steel’s romance with Lois Lane begins to blossom just as three villains from Krypton - who all have powers to match Superman’s - arrive on Earth with the intention of destroying the planet. With the help of arch-criminal Lex Luthor, the three locate Superman and when the truth is uncovered about Superman’s past - he being the son of their jailer - they seek to avenge Jor-El by killing his only son. The battle between Good and Evil culminates in a spectacular duel above Metropolis, and ends back at Superman’s home, where with a tricky manoeuvre, Superman restores order and peace on Earth. Cast includes: Christopher Reeve, Margot Kidder, Gene Hackman and Terrence Stamp.

The battle between Good and Evil culminates in a spectacular duel above Metropolis, and ends back at Superman’s home, where with a tricky manoeuvre, Superman restores order and peace on Earth. Cast includes: Christopher Reeve, Margot Kidder, Gene Hackman and Terrence Stamp.
description_for_label: In this sequel to “Superman: the movie”, the Man of Steel’s romance with Lois Lane begins to blossom just as three villains from Krypton - who all have powers to match Superman’s - arrive on Earth with the intention of destroying the planet. With the help of arch-criminal Lex Luthor, the three locate Superman and when the truth is uncovered about Superman’s past - he being the son of their jailer - they seek to avenge Jor-El by killing his only son. The battle between Good and Evil culminates in a spectacular duel above Metropolis, and ends back at Superman’s home, where with a tricky manoeuvre, Superman restores order and peace on Earth. Cast includes: Christopher Reeve, Margot Kidder, Gene Hackman and Terrence Stamp.
